senses.de: Having a big effect or importance.
senses.ex: Everyone was surprised by the significant change in his attitude.

Tips.title: Impact Level
Tips.description: Use 'significant' to express a strong influence or considerable importance in many contexts.
Tips.example: The CEO's decision had a significant impact on the company's direction.

Tips.title: Not Always Positive
Tips.description: 'Significant' can refer to both positive and negative outcomes.
Tips.example: The storm had a significant effect on the small village.

Tips.title: Surprising Changes
Tips.description: Use it when an event or change is unexpected and worth noting.
Tips.example: His resignation was significant, few had anticipated it.

senses.ex: There's a significant difference between the two sets of data.

Tips.title: Academic Precision
Tips.description: In academic or statistical contexts, 'significant' often implies evidence-based importance.
Tips.example: The study found a significant correlation between diet and health.

Tips.title: Not Just Noticeable
Tips.description: In statistics, 'significant' means more than noticeable; it suggests a meaningful relationship.
Tips.example: The treatment led to a significant reduction in symptoms.

senses.de: Describes something that has a special or hidden meaning.
senses.ex: Her significant glance at him suggested that he should follow her.

Tips.title: Subtle Communication
Tips.description: 'Significant' can imply subtle, non-verbal communication with deeper meaning.
Tips.example: Her significant smile conveyed her approval without words.

Tips.title: Hidden Messages
Tips.description: It often indicates a message intended only for certain people to understand.
Tips.example: The spies exchanged significant looks across the room.

Considerable.wordDefinition:
Considerable means a large amount or great in size, while significant means having an important or noticeable effect.

Considerable usually describes something that is large in quantity or size. For example, "There was a considerable amount of ice on the road.".

Considerable describes the amount or size of something, while significant describes the impact or effect of something.

Critical.wordDefinition:
Critical means extremely important or crucial.

It describes a situation that is urgent or requires immediate attention. For example, if someone is in critical condition, it means they are in a very serious state and need urgent medical attention.

Both words can describe things that are important, but critical is used for situations that require urgent action or attention, while significant is used for things that have meaning or value.

Crucial.wordDefinition:
Crucial means extremely important or essential, meaning that something cannot be done without it. It usually implies that something is necessary for the success or failure of a task or goal.

For example: "Sleep is crucial for the human body to function properly."

Crucial is applicable when something is absolutely necessary for success, while significant is more appropriate when stressing the importance or impact of something.

Important.wordDefinition:
Important means something that has value, worth or meaning.

Both words are applicable in different situations, depending on the context. For example, a knowledge or skill that is important for a particular job may not necessarily be significant in terms of its impact on society.

A discovery that may not seem important at first glance may turn out to be significant in terms of its impact on science or technology.

Important generally refers to value or usefulness, while significant refers to impact or consequence.

Key.wordDefinition:
Key refers to something that is important or essential to understanding or achieving something else. For example, in music, a key signature is the set of notes that a piece of music is played in, and it is essential to know the key signature in order to play the piece correctly.

In cryptography, a key is a code or password that is essential to unlocking encrypted information.

Key usually implies a more direct or essential relationship to something else, while significant refers more to the importance or impact of something in a broader context.

Meaningful.wordDefinition:
The words meaningful and significant both refer to the importance or value of something, but they are used in slightly different ways.

Meaningful refers to something that has personal or emotional value to an individual. For example, a meaningful experience might be a trip to a place that has special memories, or a conversation with a loved one that brings a sense of connection or understanding.

The term meaningful is often used in the context of personal relationships, experiences, or beliefs.

Meaningful describes personal value, while significant describes broader-scale importance or impact.

Momentous.wordDefinition:
Momentous and significant are both adjectives used to describe events or things that are noteworthy, but they have slightly different meanings.

Momentous refers to an event or situation that is very important because it will have a great impact on the future or is a very significant turning point in history.

Example: The momentous election of Barack Obama as the first Black president of the United States.

Momentous is typically used to describe large-scale, history-changing events, while significant describes anything that is important or meaningful, regardless of the scale.

Notable.wordDefinition:
Both notable and significant have similar meanings, as they both refer to something that is important or worthy of attention.

However, notable usually suggests that the thing being described is well-known or famous, while significant suggests that it has a particular importance or impact.

For example, a notable person would be someone who is famous or well-known, such as a celebrity or historical figure, whereas a significant event might be something that has a big impact on history or people's lives, such as a war or scientific discovery.

Notable tends to be used more for people or things that are famous, while significant tends to be used more for events or situations that have a particular impact or importance.

Pertinent.wordDefinition:
Pertinent refers to something that is relevant or directly related to a certain topic, issue, or situation.

For example, if we were discussing the effects of climate change on ocean life, a pertinent fact would be the increase in ocean acidity levels.

Pertinent refers to something that is relevant or directly related, while significant refers to something that has a substantial or meaningful impact.

Relevant.wordDefinition:
Relevant means that something is related or connected to a certain topic or situation, and has an impact on it.

For example, if you're writing an essay about climate change, statistics on greenhouse gas emissions would be relevant because they are related to the topic and add to your argument.

Relevant refers to how things are connected or related, while significant refers to the importance or impact of something.

Substantial.wordDefinition:
The words significant and substantial are similar in meaning but have slightly different uses. Significant means something is important or meaningful, usually in a specific context, such as a study or experiment.

Substantial means something is large in size or amount, often used to describe physical objects, quantities or sums of money.

For example, you might use substantial to describe a store discount that's more than 50%, or the weight of a large rock.

Significant describes importance, while substantial describes size or quantity.

Weighty.wordDefinition:
Weighty means that something has a lot of importance or influence.

It is often used when referring to a decision or issue that carries a lot of responsibility or consequences. For example, a weighty decision might be one that involves a lot of money or affects many people's lives.

In summary, while both words imply a level of importance, significant refers to something that has an impact, while weighty refers to something that carries a lot of responsibility or consequences.

quotes.Text: To spend more money, you have to have more money, but time is fixed and we all have the same amount to spare. How we choose to spend it can make a significant difference on the impact we have in our careers or in the world.
quotes.Title: English Author
quotes.Name: Simon Sinek

quotes.Text: All significant truths are private truths. As they become public they cease to become truths; they become facts, or at best, part of the public character; or at worst, catchwords.
quotes.Title: American Poet
quotes.Name: T. S. Eliot

quotes.Text: We can all be successful and make money, but when we die, that ends. But when you are significant is when you help other people be successful. That lasts many a lifetime.
quotes.Title: American Coach
quotes.Name: Lou Holtz

quotes.Text: This is an important book, the critic assumes, because it deals with war. This is an insignificant book because it deals with the feelings of women in a drawing-room.
quotes.Title: British Author
quotes.Name: Virginia Woolf

quotes.Text: The capacity for hope is the most significant fact of life. It provides human beings with a sense of destination and the energy to get started.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Norman Cousins

quotes.Text: It seems essential, in relationships and all tasks, that we concentrate only on what is most significant and important.
quotes.Title: Danish Philosopher
quotes.Name: Soren Kierkegaard

quotes.Text: The challenge of work-life balance is without question one of the most significant struggles faced by modern man.
quotes.Title: American Educator
quotes.Name: Stephen Covey

quotes.Text: Whatever you do may seem insignificant to you, but it is most important that you do it.
quotes.Title: Indian Leader
quotes.Name: Mahatma Gandhi

quotes.Text: There is nothing insignificant in the world. It all depends on the point of view.
quotes.Title: German Writer
quotes.Name: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

quotes.Text: What an insignificant life is this which I am now leading!
quotes.Title: Scottish Lawyer
quotes.Name: James Boswell
